title: Masonry Shear Wall Design for In-Plane Loads
problem: A 12-in fully grouted reinforced masonry shear wall is 20 ft long and 14 ft high. The wall carries a dead load of 10,000 lb/ft (including wall weight) and a live load of 2,000 lb/ft. The in-plane seismic load (E) at the top of the wall is 80 kips. The masonry compressive strength is $f'_m = 2,500$ psi, and the steel yield strength is $f_y = 60,000$ psi. Determine if the wall is adequate for shear and flexure using the strength design provisions of TMS 402. Check the shear capacity and the need for horizontal reinforcement. Assume the wall has #6 vertical bars at 48 in on center and #4 horizontal bars at 16 in on center. Use $d = 0.8L$ for flexural lever arm.
given: Total wall length for axial: $L = 20$ ft, so total $P_D = 200$ kips, $P_L = 40$ kips
In-plane seismic load at top: $V_u = 80$ kips
Reinforcement: #6 vertical @ 48 in o.c., #4 horizontal @ 16 in o.c.
required: Check if the wall has adequate shear capacity.
Check if the wall has adequate flexural capacity.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Axial Load for Seismic Load Combination
solution_steps.content:
Per ASCE 7-16 Section 12.4.2.3, for strength design, use the seismic load combination:
$$P_u = 1.2D + 1.0E + 1.0L + 0.2S$$
For this problem, ignore snow and reduce live load per ASCE 7 Section 12.4.2.3 (permitted to use 0.5L for parking, but for typical walls, use full L if not specified). Assume full L for conservatism.

$$P_u = 1.2 \times 200 + 0.5 \times 40 + 0.2 \times 0$$
Note: TMS 402 Section 9.1.9.2 allows reduction of live load for seismic combinations. Use $0.5L$ per ASCE 7-16 Section 12.4.2.3.

$$P_u = 240 + 20 = 260 \text{ kips}$$

Axial load per unit length: $p_u = 260 / 20 = 13 \text{ kip/ft}$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Nominal Shear Strength Provided by Masonry
solution_steps.content:
TMS 402 Section 9.3.4.1.2 gives nominal shear strength for reinforced masonry:
$$V_n = V_{nm} + V_{ns}$$

Where:
$$V_{nm} = \left[4.0 - 1.75 \left(\frac{M}{Vd_v}\right)\right] A_{cv} \sqrt{f'_m} + 0.25 P_u$$
But not less than $A_{cv} \sqrt{f'_m}$ and not greater than $6A_{cv} \sqrt{f'_m}$.

For shear walls, $M/(Vd_v)$ can be taken as $h/L = 14/20 = 0.7$ if not known exactly.

$A_{cv} = L \times t = 240 \times 12 = 2,880 \text{ in}^2$

$\sqrt{f'_m} = \sqrt{2,500} = 50$ psi.

First term: $4.0 - 1.75(0.7) = 4.0 - 1.225 = 2.775$

$V_{nm} = [2.775 \times 2,880 \times 50/1000] + 0.25 \times 260$
Convert psi to ksi: $50$ psi = $0.050$ ksi
$2.775 \times 2,880 \times 0.050 = 2.775 \times 144 = 399.6$ kips
Add $0.25 \times 260 = 65$ kips

$V_{nm} = 399.6 + 65 = 464.6$ kips

Check lower limit: $A_{cv} \sqrt{f'_m} = 2,880 \times 0.050 = 144$ kips, OK.
Check upper limit: $6A_{cv} \sqrt{f'_m} = 6 \times 144 = 864$ kips, OK.

So $V_{nm} = 464.6$ kips.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Nominal Shear Strength Provided by Reinforcement
solution_steps.content:
TMS 402 Section 9.3.4.1.3:
$$V_{ns} = 0.5 \left(\frac{A_v}{s}\right) f_y d_v$$

Where $A_v$ is area of horizontal reinforcement within spacing $s$, $d_v$ is effective shear depth = $0.8L = 192$ in.

For #4 horizontal bars @ 16 in o.c.: $A_v = 2 \times 0.20 = 0.40$ in² (two legs).

$$V_{ns} = 0.5 \times \left(\frac{0.40}{16}\right) \times 60 \times 192$$
$$V_{ns} = 0.5 \times 0.025 \times 60 \times 192$$
$$V_{ns} = 0.5 \times 0.025 \times 11,520 = 0.5 \times 288 = 144 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Total Nominal Shear Strength and Check Capacity
solution_steps.content:
$$V_n = V_{nm} + V_{ns} = 464.6 + 144 = 608.6 \text{ kips}$$

Strength reduction factor for shear in masonry (TMS 402 Section 9.3.4.2.2): $\phi = 0.80$.

$$\phi V_n = 0.80 \times 608.6 = 486.9 \text{ kips}$$

Applied $V_u = 80$ kips.

$80 \text{ kips} < 486.9 \text{ kips}$, so shear is adequate.

solution_steps.title: Check Minimum Horizontal Reinforcement
solution_steps.content:
TMS 402 Section 9.3.4.2.3 requires minimum horizontal reinforcement ratio:
$$\rho_h \ge 0.0007$$

For #4 @ 16 in o.c.:
$A_v$ per foot = $0.40 \times (12/16) = 0.30$ in²/ft
$\rho_h = 0.30 / (12 \times 12) = 0.30 / 144 = 0.00208 > 0.0007$, OK.

solution_steps.title: Check Flexural Capacity
solution_steps.content:
First, determine vertical steel area.
#6 bars @ 48 in o.c.: $A_s$ per foot = $0.44 \times (12/48) = 0.11$ in²/ft
Total steel in wall: $A_s = 0.11 \times 20 = 2.2$ in².

Check minimum vertical reinforcement per TMS 402 Section 9.3.5.2.1: $\rho_v \ge 0.0007$
$\rho_v = 2.2 / (240 \times 12) = 2.2 / 2,880 = 0.00076 > 0.0007$, OK.

For flexure, treat as a rectangular section with $b = 12$ in, $d = 192$ in.

Compute $a = \frac{A_s f_y}{0.80 f'_m b}$ (TMS 402 Section 9.3.3.2.1, with factor 0.80 for f'm).
$$a = \frac{2.2 \times 60}{0.80 \times 2.5 \times 12} = \frac{132}{24} = 5.5 \text{ in}$$

Nominal moment capacity:
$$M_n = A_s f_y \left(d - \frac{a}{2}\right)$$
$$M_n = 2.2 \times 60 \times \left(192 - \frac{5.5}{2}\right)$$
$$M_n = 132 \times (192 - 2.75) = 132 \times 189.25 = 24,981 \text{ in-kips}$$
$$M_n = 2,082 \text{ ft-kips}$$

Strength reduction factor for flexure (TMS 402 Section 9.3.3.2): $\phi = 0.90$.

$$\phi M_n = 0.90 \times 2,082 = 1,874 \text{ ft-kips}$$

Applied moment at base of wall (from $V_u$ at top):
$$M_u = V_u \times h = 80 \times 14 = 1,120 \text{ ft-kips}$$

$1,120 < 1,874$, so flexure is adequate.

final_answer: The shear wall is adequate. The shear capacity is $\phi V_n = 487$ kips > $V_u = 80$ kips, and the flexural capacity is $\phi M_n = 1,874$ ft-kips > $M_u = 1,120$ ft-kips.
